Award.AwardTitle: The Neural Mechanisms of Memory for Object Shape and Motion: Integrating Evidence from fMRI, ERPs, and TMS

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
It has been hypothesized that memory is constructive in nature, where features or components from disparate brain regions combine to form a unified memory. Consistent with this view, it has been shown that memory for objects or sounds can activate the corresponding visual or auditory cortical processing regions. Furthermore, memory for specific categories of objects can activate the corresponding processing regions (e.g., memory for faces can activate face processing regions). However, there is little evidence that memory can activate regions that process detailed features, such as object color, motion, or shape, which would be expected if the constructive memory hypothesis is correct. Through support from the National Science Foundation, Dr. Scott Slotnick and his students at Boston College will investigate whether memory can activate such feature specific processing regions. In particular, it will be determined whether memory for motion can activate motion processing regions and whether memory for shape can activate shape processing regions (and whether such activity is essential for memory). The role of classic memory related cortical regions, namely, the prefrontal cortex and parietal cortex, will also be evaluated in relation to activity in feature processing regions. This research will be conducted by integrating functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI), to identify the precise spatial location of cortical activity, event-related potential (ERP) source localization, to identify the precise timing of cortical activity, and transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS), to identify whether a cortical region of interest is necessary for memory.

This project will provide the most compelling evidence bearing on the constructive memory hypothesis to date. While the combination of fMRI and ERP source localization or fMRI and TMS have been used to study visual perception and attention, these combined methodologies have not been used to study memory or other cognitive functions. As such, the techniques developed to conduct this research will serve as a methodological framework for future cognitive neuroscience studies. Funding of this project will also foster the growth of the neuroscience program at Boston College through direct participation of graduate and undergraduate students in the research, and by providing the basis for new courses that will focus on methods in cognitive neuroscience. More broadly, this project will assess whether memory can be specific for item features, which could explain certain types of memory loss in patients and could also have implications for law (relating to the level of detail in eyewitness testimony).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Through funding provided by this NSF grant, Dr. Slotnick at Boston College has made new discoveries about how visual memories are constructed from the visual building blocks in our brains. Every time we look at an object, our brains first break it into its components, as indicated by activation in cortical regions associated with processing individual features (such as shape, color, location, or motion), and then this feature information is used to construct our percept of an intact object. Like perception, memory has been described as constructive in nature, where features that are processed in different cortical regions are combined. In support of this, there has been some evidence for reactivation of feature processing regions during retrieval (e.g., memory for items in color, but not memory for gray items, reactivates color processing cortex). However, it is uncertain whether such feature-specific reactivation is necessary for accurate remembering or is epiphenomenal (i.e., not functional, like the heat given off by a light bulb).

 

This NSF grant has funded 9 publications in peer-reviewed journals to date. This project is the first in the field of memory to integrate results from functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI, a technique with excellent spatial resolution but limited temporal resolution), event-related potentials (ERPs, a technique with excellent temporal resolution but limited spatial resolution), and transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS, a technique that can be used to determine whether a cortical region is necessary for a given mental process). In one study, 1 Hz TMS was used to disrupt motion processing region MT and, following the constructive view of memory, it was hypothesized that this would selectively impair memory for motion. At study, moving or stationary abstract shapes were presented to the left or right of a central fixation cross (participants were instructed to always look directly at this cross). At test, shapes from the study phase were presented at the center of the screen and participants classified each shape as previously “moving" or "stationary". Each participant first completed an fMRI session to localize MT on the surface of each hemisphere (Figure 1, left). Then, fMRI guided TMS was applied to MT for 10 minutes between the study and test phases to disrupt processing in this region within one hemisphere and then the other hemisphere. Figure 1 (right) shows the results. In support of the hypothesis under investigation, disruption of MT did not impair memory for previously stationary items (i.e., TMS memory accuracy and control memory accuracy were similar), but disruption of MT did impair memory for previously moving items (i.e., TMS memory accuracy was worse than control memory accuracy). Of additional relevance, following disruption of MT, memory for previously moving items was no different than chance. The latter result indicates that when motion processing region MT is disrupted, it completely wipes out memory for motion. The present results provide the first evidence that feature processing region activity is necessary for accurate remembering (i.e., activity is not epiphenomenal). These results also provide compelling support for the view that memory, like perception, is a constructive process, where information is combined from different feature processing regions of the brain.

 

This NSF grant has also supported contributions with regard to broader impacts. A novel ERP temporal correlation technique was developed that can be used to assess whether activity is synchronized in different regions of the brain, which is important because it can be inferred that synchronized brain regions operate together during a given mental process.
